name: Batata Vada
history: Batata Vada, originating in Maharashtra, India, is a popular street food and snack. It's a savory, spicy potato fritter that's a staple in Marathi cuisine and has gained popularity across India.
description: Batata Vada consists of a spicy potato filling encased in a gram flour batter and deep-fried until golden and crispy. It's often served with green chutney or sandwiched in a bun (Vada Pav).

equipment.name: mixing bowl
equipment.description: For preparing the batter and filling.

instructions.title: Prepare the Potato Filling
instructions.description: Heat oil in a pan. Add mustard seeds, green chilies, curry leaves, turmeric powder, and salt. Add the mashed potatoes and mix well. Set aside to cool.

instructions.title: Make the Batter
instructions.description: In a bowl, mix gram flour, red chili powder, asafoetida, and water to make a smooth, thick batter.

instructions.title: Shape the Vadas
instructions.description: Divide the potato mixture into equal portions. Shape each into a ball.

instructions.title: Deep Fry the Vadas
instructions.description: Heat oil in a frying pan. Dip each potato ball in the batter, ensuring it's evenly coated. Deep fry until golden and crispy.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the Batata Vadas hot with green chutney or sandwiched in a bun as Vada Pav.

tips: The batter should be thick enough to coat the potato balls.
Fry on medium heat to ensure the vadas are cooked evenly without burning.
variations: Aloo Bonda: Use a similar filling but make the batter with rice flour for a different texture.
Masala Vada: Add chopped onions and garlic to the potato mixture for extra flavor.

storage.shelfLife: Best eaten fresh but can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Reheat in an oven or on a pan until crispy before serving.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat in a preheated oven at 180°C (350°F) for about 10 minutes or until crispy.
presentationTips: Serve on a plate lined with paper to absorb excess oil.
Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves and sliced onions.
